Crash-Coursing Python

User-friendly, but long :P

Posted by ex0dus on June 12, 2016

Python is programming langauge written by Guido van Ross… blah blah.

Anyway, if you are here with me, I’m pretty sure you know what the Python Programming language is. I’m not going to explain it. This is an interactive tutorial. Time to conduct some research for yourself now :P

So today, I’m going to cover the basics of the Python programming languages. Keep in mind that this is a crash-course, and therefore it is for the experienced programmer. Well not necessarily, but just someone who is familiar with code.

Note: I have embedded Trinket.io, which is an interactive python interpreter and IDLE.

Use this! I know for a fact many people are quite lazy, so therefore, I’ve decided to implement Trinket.io’s web-based Python IDLE and interpreter. When executing code, you may use this to do so.

All the code in this tutorial will be in Python 2. NOT 3.

Let’s get started.

First, Python is interpreter-based. Think of a language that is interpreter-based being a cookbook. You will read a step, do that step, and then move on the next. That is the essential concept of an interpreter-based programming language. Each line of code is examined before execution. A compiler-based programming language, or commonly referred as object-oriented, is like reading all the steps in the cookbook, and THEN completing each step.

Python is battery-included this means that Python comes with its own integrated development environment, called IDLE.

Of course, that’s great news for Windows users. If you are a Linux user, Python is probably already installed. No big whoop.

# python
Python 2.7.11+ (default, Apr 17 2016, 14:00:29)
[GCC 5.3.1 20160409] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>>

Input and Output

Often times, when we learn code, we start off writing the canonical Hello World program.

In this crash course, you can either 1. use the Python IDLE on Linux 2. Use a text editor or some sort of code editor (Nano, Vim, Atom), save a .py file, and run. 3. Use Trinket.io

The function for output is simple.

print "Hello world!"

No preprocessor directives, no int main() starting point, no semicolons. Plain and simple output. The function for input is:

x = input()

We declare a variable, called x and declare it to the function input, with parentheses. This will allow the user to store a value into x. No strings though, I’ll explain in just a sec. We can pass text in the parentheses as well, as demonstrated.

>>> x = input("Give me a number! ")
Give me a number! 12
>>> x
12

Next, if we want it to input a string, we call the raw_input function.

>>> x = raw_input("Pass me a string! ")
Pass me a string! Hello
>>> x
'Hello'

Comments

You make a comment using a #. Multiline comments are created and ended with three ‘.

#This is a comment.
'''This is a multiline comment.
   See? I can write a lot!'''

Variables and Variable Declaration

Variables are generic in Python. This means that they do not need to be declared with types such as “int”, “double”, “char”. and etc, as in seen in languages such as C and C++. Variables can be assigned to strings.

x = 12
y = 'Strings can be made with single quotes'
z = " or double quotes"

Math

Math is common sense in most programming languages.

1 + 2 = 3 # addition
